contents.title: The Panopticon Singularity
contents.generated_title: The Panopticon Singularity
contents.description_html: Though originally proposed as a humane experiment in penal reform in 1785, Bentham's idea has eerie resonances today. One of the risks of the technologies that may give rise to a singularity is that they may also permit the construction of a Panopticon society -- a police state characterised by omniscient surveillance and mechanical law enforcement.
contents.description: Though originally proposed as a humane experiment in penal reform in 1785, Bentham's idea has eerie resonances today. One of the risks of the technologies that may give rise to a singularity is that they may also permit the construction of a Panopticon society -- a police state characterised by omniscient surveillance and mechanical law enforcement.

source.title: The Panopticon Singularity

contents.generated_title: Untitled
contents.content_html: A Panopticon Singularity is the logical outcome if the burgeoning technologies of the singularity are funneled into automating law enforcement. Previous police states were limited by manpower, but the panopticon singularity substitutes technology, and ultimately replaces human conscience with a brilliant but merciless prosthesis.

contents.title: Are We Opting Into Global Surveillance? - Towards Data Science
contents.generated_title: Are We Opting Into Global Surveillance? - Towards Data Science
contents.description_html: When George Orwell wrote 1984, he painted the picture of a society operating under government-regulated surveillance. Orwell never imagined a world where people chose surveillance over privacy; Big Brother was a requirement not a choice. However, he wrote the novel in the 1940s, which was decades before everyone walked around with handheld devices that track location, voice and personal information.

contents.title: Dehumanization in organizational settings: some scientific and ethical considerations
contents.generated_title: Dehumanization in organizational settings: some scientific and ethical considerations
contents.description_html: Dehumanizing attitudes and behaviors frequently occur in organizational settings and are often viewed as an acceptable, and even necessary, strategy for pursuing personal and organizational goals. Here I examine a number of commonly held beliefs about dehumanization and argue that there is relatively little support for them in light of the evidence emerging from social psychological and neuroscientific research.
